description: From Middle English slough (“skin, husk, rind; cocoon; scales; cyst”), akin to Middle High German slûch (“slough”) (whence German Schlauch (“tube, hose”)).

entries.meaning: Alternative spelling of slough (skin shed by a snake or other reptile).
examples: That is the sluff of a rattler; we must be careful.

entries.meaning: Alternative spelling of slough (dead skin on a sore or ulcer).
examples: This is the sluff that came off of his skin after the burn.

entries.meaning: An avalanche, mudslide, or a like slumping of material or debris.

verbs.description: sluff (third-person singular simple present sluffs, present participle sluffing, simple past and past participle sluffed)

entries.meaning: Alternative spelling of slough (to shed or to slide off).
(transitive, Utah, Idaho) To play truant from (school).
examples: Both calls told her the same thing — that her son had been sluffing school. She felt betrayed. She had trusted this child.
